titles.title: Masou Kishin Cybuster
Masou Kishin Cybaster
Lord of Elementals Cybaster
God Elemental Machine of the Wind Cybaster
Elemental God-Machine Cybaster
Demonic Armor Cybuster
Cybaster - La Divina Macchina Elementale
Cybaster
魔装機神サイバスター
Psybuster
Cybaster

relatedanime.anime: Super Robot Taisen: Original Generation - The Animation
Super Robot Taisen: Original Generation - Divine Wars

anime.description: In 2040, the continuous pollution and the mysterious series of earthquakes left the city of Tokyo in ruins. A young man named Ken Ando is in training to become a member of DC, a paramilitary organization designed to investigate and protect the collapsing environment. Ken, with the support from his sick sister, Sayuri, gives his best to become a part of the elite group that the young longs for, but he receives the devastating news of being cut from the team because of his poor performances in the evaluation sessions. Then, an ominous monster suddenly appears from the sky with a blinding flash and starts mowing down DC`s working robots with mysterious invisible forces. Ken, eager to show what he is truly made of, gets into one of the working robots and imprudently engages in a battle with the monster. Source: Geneon

externalentity.identifier: 魔装機神サイバスター_(テレビアニメ)

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: setting
tag.description: The setting describes in what time and place an anime takes place. To a certain extent it describes what you can expect from the world in the anime.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: time
tag.description: This placeholder lists different epochs in human history and more vague but important timelines such as the future, the present and the past.

tag.name: place
tag.description: The places the anime can take place in. Includes more specific places such as a country on Earth, as well as more general places such as a dystopia or a mirror world.

tag.name: future
tag.description: Anime that fall under the future category are the ones that have a society that could have originated from ours. In most cases it should go hand to hand with sci-fi since we expect the future to consist of advanced technology, however, in the case where it`s explicitly stated in the story that the anime takes place "x years into the future", the state of technology doesn`t matter as long as it`s long into the future. The anime can be set in an alternative universe not tied with our own, as long as it has a futuristic feel to it. This category sports quite a lot of anime, mostly stemming from SciFi, but not necessarily only from there.

tag.name: fictional location
tag.description: A fictional location is a place or world which is run by different set of rules than our common and ordinary world. This may include completely fictional worlds with no semblance of Earth, computer-generated worlds, fantasy worlds, magical worlds, parallel worlds accessible through portals, and so on. Or it may be fictional places like floating islands, dungeons or planets, which can co-exist with ordinary Earth, but are otherwise separate from it. A world that generally shares the characteristics of, and/or is generally indistinguishable from the real world (bar research on a "more than cursory" level), would NOT be considered a fictional world. A good example is http://anidb.net/a4521 [Code Geass]. It contains several real world nationalities, such as http://anidb.net/a4521 [China], http://anidb.net/t2672 [Japan] (now Area 11), http://anidb.net/t5091 [India], etc, along with fictional nationalities such as http://anidb.net/t2361 [Britannia]. China, Japan, and India are easily identified with a cursory look. The location is unmistakably the planet Earth, even though national borders have been redrawn. The fictional world should only be tagged if it plays a materially important role in the plot and setting; generally, an episodic occurrence of a fictional world should not be tagged. A fantasy world is a type of fictional world, part of a fictional universe. Typical worlds involve, but are not limited to: magic or magical abilities, and/or a medieval theme. Some examples include: a parallel world tenuously connected to Earth via magical portals or items; a fictional Earth-like planet in the remote past or future; or an entirely independent world set in another universe. Many fantasy worlds draw heavily on real world history, geography, and sociology, and also on folklore.

tag.name: Earth
tag.description: The Earth is the third planet from the Sun, and the densest and fifth-largest of the eight planets in the Solar System. It is in effect a ball of hot mud, but on the surface it`s cold enough, so most of us live on it (or are supposed to). It is circa 4.5 billion years old, and, unless we humans succeed in destroying it over the next couple of centuries, it is expected to last for quite another while, though the changes in the Sun`s emissions due to its aging will likely cause the extinction of everything; the species of earthlings are guaranteed to die, even if we fail to kill them -- unless, of course, we find ourselves another planet and figure out a way to take everything there. Our little planet on a corner of this galaxy may mean nothing in the grand scheme of things, but to its inhabitants it is their home, so, as a species, we cherish it dearly, to the point many cultures even to this day deify it. Being the home to the human civilizations, the Earth is the main setting of most fiction, be it anime or otherwise, but not only are many titles set in other places, such as unrelated fantasy worlds, in a considerable number of fictional titles the Earth is actually destroyed by aggressive alien invaders.

tag.name: mecha
tag.description: Mecha in Japanese basically means mechanical things; everything from an electric whisk or a car to a spaceship or a robot. Here however we limit it to the more exotic things usually referred to as mecha anime: robots, whether controlled by a human or not, and their ilk. See Androids, Piloted Robots, Power Suits, Robot Helpers, Transforming Robots for a more specific classification.

tag.name: Japan
tag.description: Japan is a sovereign island nation in East Asia. Located in the Pacific Ocean, it lies off the eastern coast of the Asian mainland and stretches from the Sea of Okhotsk in the north to the East China Sea and China in the southwest. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: Tokyo
tag.description: Tokyo, officially Tokyo Metropolis, is the capital city of Japan and one of its 47 prefectures. The Greater Tokyo Area is the most populous metropolitan area in the world. It is the seat of the Emperor of Japan and the Japanese government. Tokyo is in the Kantou region on the southeastern side of the main island Honshu and includes the Izu Islands and Ogasawara Islands. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: game
tag.description: Based on an interactive (even if minimally so) form of entertainment software, generally available for PCs, consoles or arcade machines.

tag.name: RPG
tag.description: Any anime that is based on a role-playing game aka RPG. A role-playing video game is a video game which includes elements of non-electronic role-playing games. The player assumes control of one or several fictional characters (a party) who have joined forces in order to perform quests and overcome a great number of challenges and enemies, usually monsters inspired by fantasy, and, to a lesser extent, science fiction and classic mythology. During the course of the game the characters, or avatars, which are generally defined by quantized characteristics, evolve and improve in that their various attributes increase, as well as by gaining more powerful artefacts.

tag.name: action game
tag.description: Any game where reflexes are the key to the gameplay, violence is optional.

tag.name: Asia
tag.description: Asia is Earth`s largest and most populous continent, located primarily in the eastern and northern hemispheres and sharing the continental landmass of Eurasia with the continent of Europe. Asia covers an area of 44,579,000 square kilometers, about 30% of Earth`s total land area and 8.7% of the Earth`s total surface area. The continent, which has long been home to the majority of the human population, was the site of many of the first civilizations. Asia is notable for not only its overall large size and population, but also dense and large settlements as well as vast barely populated regions within the continent of 4.4 billion people. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: parallel world
tag.description: A parallel world, parallel universe, or alternative reality is a self-contained separate reality coexisting with our own. Because "alternative reality" sometimes implies that the reality is a variant of our own, like for example a mirror world, we use the term "parallel world/universe" which is more general, without any connotations implying a relationship (or lack thereof) with our own world/universe (meaning a fictional world can just as well have an alternative reality, it doesn`t need to be our reality). To put it more simply, this category is to show if more than 1 world/universe/reality is present in the anime. Multiple timelines of the same world/universe/reality are NOT considered parallel worlds. For example, in http://anidb.net/a7729 [Steins;Gate] the cast travels through multiple "World Lines", which are defined as parallel timelines of the same universe had various events occurred with differing outcomes.

tag.name: action
tag.description: Action anime usually involve a fairly straightforward story of good guys versus bad guys, where most disputes are resolved by using physical force. It often contains a lot of shooting, explosions and fighting.

tag.name: science fiction
tag.description: Science fiction stories usually focus on how situations could be different in the future when we are more technologically advanced; due to either our own achievements or having met with other civilizations whom we have learned from.

tag.name: friendship
tag.description: The feeling of trust, kindness, and friendship between a group of high school students for example, is a central theme of this anime.

tag.name: disaster
tag.description: A disaster is a large-scale situation that causes great loss of or damage or threat to life, health, property, society, or the environment, irrespective of its source or cause. Disasters have substantial, long-lasting negative repercussions, and great effort must be spent in order to undo or mitigate their effects.

tag.name: post-apocalyptic
tag.description: An anime that takes place on future Earth (or it could be an alternative universe) after a major cataclysm has occurred. World War III, an alien invasion, plague, global warming or some other general disaster are common themes to build a post-apocalyptic world upon, where the effects were severe enough that mankind barely survived. The time frame may be immediately after the catastrophe, focusing on the travails or psychology of survivors, or considerably later, often including the theme that the existence of pre-catastrophe civilization has been forgotten (or mythologised). Post-apocalyptic stories often take place in an agrarian, non-technological future world, or a world where only scattered elements of technology remain. There is a considerable degree of blurring between post-apocalyptic fiction and that which deals with false utopias or dystopian societies.

tag.name: unsorted
tag.description: a bunch of tags that still need to be either deleted or moved into proper places.

tag.name: spiritual powers
tag.description: A reality where spiritual or supernatural power is shown to exist in the world, objects, or in characters (not the same as spell-craft, science, or fantasy based powers).

tag.name: Tokyo destroyed
tag.description: Tokyo is depicted as being or having been destroyed, either partially or completely, by some sort of disaster, such as a nuclear blast, a very large-scale fire, or rising sea levels. Should the situation be dire enough, Tokyo may be destroyed again after a recovery, or a new Tokyo may be built and subsequently destroyed, by a new disaster.

tag.name: saving the world
tag.description: While villains love to take over the world or cause the end of the world as we know it, the heroes are most likely motivated by the polar opposite, saving the world. A fairly simple plot/motivation related to for great justice and what not, this trope is pretty broad and very common for many stories not focused on character interaction only. Source: TV Trope

tag.name: daikaijuu
tag.description: Literally translating to giant monster, daikaiju is an element found often in Japanese entertainment. Although usually for the science fiction genre it is also often used in horror, fantasy, mecha, and to a lesser extent comedy. Any monster that towers over a house technically qualifies as a daikaiju. Some anime, usually mecha, will go as far as calling their daikaiju with a specific title.

tag.name: anti-climactic end
tag.description: The story in this anime and the character development were building up so some special point, and the viewer will probably have been looking forward to this resolution. But the ending was a let-down. This may have several reasons, e.g. it may simply be "bad" story-telling, or the animation studio ran out of money and had to prematurely end the story.

tag.name: adults are useless
tag.description: For when adults can`t do anything right.

tag.name: military is useless
tag.description: The regular military force per se or certain units thereof are way out of their league when trying to take on the usually vastly superior foes (e.g. powerful aliens). Thus the regular military is completely useless. Often, only children (of all people) with special abilities and/or powered suits can defend Earth.

tag.name: end of the world
tag.description: The imminent end of the world may range from the total destruction of the planet Earth, to the destruction of Earth`s surface, or to the point where human life on the planet is no longer possible, aka the end of humanity. In any case it looks grim, and the protagonists battle to preserve what they can.

tag.name: tropes
tag.description: A trope is a commonly recurring literary and rhetorical devices, motifs or clichés in creative works. This use is a broader redefining of a literary trope, the use of figurative language, via word, phrase, or even an image, for artistic effect, such as using a figure of speech. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: ending tags that need merging
tag.description: See also: http://anidb.net/post426253 [http://anidb.net/post426253] and http://anidb.net/c6774745 [http://anidb.net/c6774745]

tag.name: speculative fiction
tag.description: Speculative fiction is an umbrella genre encompassing fiction with certain elements that do not exist in the real world, often in the context of supernatural, futuristic or other imaginative themes. This includes, but is not limited to, science fiction, fantasy, superhero fiction, horror, utopian and dystopian fiction, fairytale fantasy, supernatural fiction, as well as combinations thereof. Source: Wikipedia

episode.title: 風の使者
Messenger of the Wind
Kaze no Shisha
episode.summary: Ken Andou`s been training hard for six months to join the DC cleanup organization, but a robot mishap on the last day puts his chance of being hired into jeopardy. Suddenly, that hardly seems important when a rampaging battle mech appears and only Ken can drive it away! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: バルシオン
Balcion
Balcion
episode.summary: That mysterious mecha keeps appearing and causing more destruction! DC unveils their own secret battle robot, Balcion, to fight back. But who`s going to pilot it? Ken finds himself in a rivalry with Lyune Frank, the daughter of DC`s founder Dr. Frank, with his hard-earned job at risk! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 東京崩壊
The Collapse of Tokyo
Tokyo Houkai
episode.summary: Things are tough for Ken and his coworkers. Nanase`s been demoted for speaking out against arming the cleanup mecha. Mizuki`s still bothered by that strange box she found, and she discovers the records of it have been wiped. They begin to suspect there`s something sinister afoot at DC... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ラ・ギアス
La Guias
La Guias
episode.summary: Balcion and DC`s newly weaponized robots face off against the invader, but when Lyune ignores orders to retreat, a terrible tragedy occurs. It seems as though the new DC cadets have lost something irreplaceable, but when the invader reappears in the very same spot, so does a glimmer of hope... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 武装訓練
Artillery Training
Busou Kunren
episode.summary: Mizuki is still shaken by the strange things she experienced in the alien world of La Guias, but Ken, Nanase, and even her own family struggle to believe her. Unfortunately, the sinister forces within DC seeking to eliminate her and the evidence that she witnessed won`t wait. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 黒い罠
Black Trap
Kuroi Wana
episode.summary: DC holds a press conference and tour of the building to explain the live-fire accident that nearly killed Mizuki, and Ken`s father takes advantage of the opportunity to search with her and Ken for the suspicious box she saw. In doing so, they discover its terrible secret... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 光る土
Glowing Soil
Hikaru Tsuchi
episode.summary: After being taken to a sanatorium near Mount Fuji, where Psybuster was last sighted, Ken`s sister Sayuri finds an injured man in the woods. When Sayuri goes missing shortly afterwards, Ken enlists DC`s help to search for her, unaware of their keen interest in the man she found. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 樹海の攻防
Offense and Defense at the Sea of Trees
Jukai no Koubou
episode.summary: Holding Masaki and Sayuri at gunpoint, Commander Saphine takes control of the situation and of Psybuster. All hope seems lost for the trainees suspicious of DC`s true aims, but as he helps secure Psybuster for transport, Ken makes an incredible discovery.... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: DC脱走
Escape from DC
DC Dassou
episode.summary: Ken, trapped in Psybuster`s cockpit and unable to communicate, finds himself facing off against DC`s battle robots - and against Lyune, piloting Balcion and equipped with a deadly new beam cannon. As DC reveals its sinister motives, he no longer has any choice but to fight! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: バルシオーネ
Balcione
Balcione
episode.summary: Ken and his friends make a daring helicopter escape with the help of Mizuki`s father. But the stakes rise higher as DC hires professional mercenaries to pilot their new, next-generation battle robots. Will the secret weapon left behind by Dr. Frank be enough to stop them? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 神の十字軍
Divine Crusaders
Kami no Juujigun
episode.summary: As Sayuri`s health worsens, Ken hesitates to leave her behind and journey to La Guias to discover the secrets of the Four Robot Gods. Meanwhile, the engineers and trainees in Dr. Frank`s secret base desperately prepare for DC`s inevitable attack... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 風と炎の精霊
The Spirits of the Wind and the Fire
Kaze to Honoo no Seirei
episode.summary: The clock is ticking as DC mobilizes to search for Psybuster and the resistance - but Psybuster is still healing from its wounds in La Guias, and the others are ill prepared to fight. Lyune makes a drastic decision to bolster their odds... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: プレシオン軍団
The Army of Prescion
Prescion Gundan
episode.summary: Psybuster and Jaifer, piloted by Ken and Masaki, return from La Guias to face off against the Prescion army. Two of the Four Robot Gods make a formidable addition to the resistance, but DC has tricks of their own up their sleeves! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 戦火の翼
A Wing in the Flames of War
Senka no Tsubasa
episode.summary: DC`s mercenaries scour the forest for traces of the resistance and of Psybuster. Mizuki and Sayuri volunteer to talk to them to defray suspicion, but how long can they keep them from connecting the dots? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 裏切りの谷
The Valley of Betrayal
Uragiri no Tani
episode.summary: Balcione, Dr. Frank`s final robot, is finally ready to be piloted - but Lyune`s jealousy flares up. Dr. Shu, head of DC, questions his subordinates about how the resistance fought them off. Who will resolve their differences first... friend or foe? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: MBH[マイクロブラックホール]砲
Micro Black Hole Cannon
Micro Black Hole Hou
episode.summary: DC creates their most devastating new weapon yet as they prepare to unleash their ultimate battle robot, Granzon. But they have a sinister contingency plan, and it involves Ken`s father... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: グランゾン
Granzon
Granzon
episode.summary: Psybuster prepares for battle with Dallas`s Prescion, while Ken`s father is held hostage. Has DC`s weapon research finally rivaled the power of one of the Four Robot Gods? And will Ken be able to fight while his father`s life hangs in the balance? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 水の魔装機神
Warrior Robot God of the Water
Mizu no Masou Kishin
episode.summary: A devastating earthquake strikes Tokyo, and Ken and his friends are unable to stand idly by. As they`re busy helping, DC plots an attack on their secret base with Granzon! Can Lyune defend it on her own, or must the resistance hope for a miracle? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 湖底の罠
The Lake Bottom Trap
Kotei no Wana
episode.summary: The Robot God of Water, Gottess, has suddenly appeared to repel Granzon`s attack with Sayuri as its pilot! But it only helped her as a momentary whim. She`ll have to visit La Guias herself to discover whether Gottess has truly chosen her... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 和睦
Peace Settlement
Waboku
episode.summary: While wandering Tokyo, devastated by earthquakes and rioting, Ken and Dallas encounter each other by chance. They should be enemies - but does DC realize the peril that Earth is in? The line between friend and foe suddenly blurs! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 望郷
Nostalgia
Boukyou
episode.summary: As the resistance suspected, DC`s peace offering was a trap, and they abandon Dallas and his wavering loyalties to a seemingly certain death. Meanwhile, with Ken and Masaki missing, Lyune and Sayuri must repel the next assault on their base alone. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ザムジード
Zamjeed
Zamjeed
episode.summary: Its employees now ruled by fear, DC has begun mass producing Granzons equipped with Micro Black Hole cannons. The threat this poses to the resistance is dwarfed by that which it poses to the worlds of Earth and La Guias themselves... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: マサキ
Masaki
Masaki
episode.summary: The Robot God of Earth, Zamjeed, has finally appeared! But Lyune, its chosen pilot, refuses to abandon her father`s Balcione. As she hesitates, DC plans a sinister wormhole experiment to strike back at the world of La Guias they so despise! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 異空間突破
Through the Dimensional Gap
Ikuukan Toppa
episode.summary: The resistance mourn the tragic loss of one of their own, and Lyune vows to atone by piloting Zamjeed. But without the strength of Jaifer, can they survive DC`s fiercest attack yet? Only a baptism by fire can save them! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 激突
The Collision
Gekitotsu
episode.summary: The Four Robot Gods and their pilots have assembled, but are they too late? DC`s reckless experiments have brought a cataclysm upon both worlds. Refusing to give up, the resistance prepares to strike back and put an end to their evil! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ラ・ギアスの攻防
Offense and Defense of La Guias
La Guias no Koubou
episode.summary: Earth and La Guias have been saved, but at a cost. Psybuster`s story is not complete without telling the tale of the lost boy from Earth with whom it all began - the hero who risked his life on both worlds to bring peace to them. Source: crunchyroll
